thread.title: Despite snub, Chris Paul staying busy off the court during All-Star Weekend
thread.title_full: Despite snub, Chris Paul staying busy off the court during All-Star Weekend

author: USA TODAY Sports
title: Despite snub, Chris Paul staying busy off the court during All-Star Weekend
text:
Let friends in your social network know what you are reading about Facebook Email Despite snub, Chris Paul staying busy off the court during All-Star Weekend Paul is helping out the community where he began his NBA career. Post to Facebook Despite snub, Chris Paul staying busy off the court during All-Star Weekend Paul is helping out the community where he began his NBA career. Check out this story on USATODAY.com: http://usat.ly/2m4OSkO Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted!   Join the Nation's Conversation   Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Despite snub, Chris Paul staying busy off the court during All-Star Weekend AJ Neuharth-Keusch , USA TODAY Sports 5:02 p.m. ET Feb. 17, 2017 CLOSE x Share USA TODAY Sports' AJ Neuharth-Keusch discusses the overabundance of top-notch guards in the NBA and how many of them were left out of this year's All-Star game. Chris Paul, Kris Dunn and Jakob Poeltl attend the unveiling with NBA Cares and State Farm of NYC Assist, a Teen Learning Center at Educational Alliance Boys & Girls Clubs. (Photo: Daniel Zuchnik, WireImage) CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
This may be the first time in nine years that Chris Paul wasn't voted into the NBA All-Star Game, but that doesn't mean the superstar point guard won't have a busy weekend down in New Orleans. 
Paul, who was snubbed from the Western Conference roster due to the NBA's absurd guard depth and a hand injury he suffered before the All-Star voting periods were over, is going to spend the weekend giving back to the community where he began his NBA career. 
On Saturday, Paul, along with State Farm and the Chris Paul Family Foundation, will unveil a new technology center at the New Orleans Dryades YMCA as part of the State Farm NBA Cares Assist Tracker program. 
"A lot of times over the years, you see different people, different guys, whoever it may be, they do endorsement deals where they just advertise their different products and that is what it is. But with State Farm, it's been a real partnership, talking about giving back," Paul said in a phone interview with USA TODAY Sports on Friday. "It's more than just the Chris and Cliff commercials ... it's really about trying to get in and impact the neighborhoods and the community. 
" ... Being in New Orleans, it's the city that sort of raised me and where I grew up. It's all about the story of coming back here and the importance of giving back and showing how to make a difference in your community."
